This aperture is half white and half black, resembling a crescent moon—hence it is called the Crescent-Moon Crucible. To know the Crescent Moon as the crucible and cauldron is to comprehend more than half of the Great Elixir’s Dao.

The White Tiger lies below as the pivot of fire’s ignition; the Azure Dragon resides above, stirring the winds and waves of ascent. Within them, true mercury transforms and flows as pearls. Thus, the Eastern Dragon and Western Tiger intertwine, yin essence and yang spirit restrain each other, divine workings circulate within the golden tripod, and sacred medicine is forged in the jade crucible. The mechanism of creation is inverted, the functions of *Qian* and *Kun* are reversed—who but the most profoundly penetrating in the world could achieve this?

When gold enters fierce fire, its color remains unaltered, and its radiance naturally emerges. Since the beginning of creation, the sun and moon have never waned in brightness; gold has never lost its weight. The sun and moon retain their constant forms, for gold is born from the moon. At the new moon, it receives the sun’s essence; when gold returns to its mother, the moon wanes, and they envelop each other, concealing their boundaries and sinking into the cavernous void. Gold regains its original nature, and its majestic radiance fills the crucible.

The sun, moon, and gold endure the longest. Since the opening of heaven and earth, the forms of the sun and moon have remained constant, never dimming in brightness; the weight of true gold has remained unchanged, never losing its luster. These three are of one body. People merely observe that when gold’s essence flourishes, the moon’s brightness doubles, knowing that gold is born from the moon—but they do not realize that the moon’s brightness originally arises from the sun. Thus, at the moment of their convergence, the moon conceals its light, sinking into the cavernous void to receive the sun’s transformation, thereby generating gold. Gold’s nature fundamentally derives from the sun, so its firmness, hardness, weight, and solidity bear the sun’s color and possess the sun’s nature. All things meet fire and none do not melt away—only gold, when placed in fire, does not lose its color. Refined a hundred times, it grows ever harder; tempered in great smelting, it becomes ever redder. Fire is the qi of the Great Yang; gold is the essence of the Great Yin. When gold enters fierce fire, it regains its original nature—thus, when the crucible’s fire blazes, gold’s color intensifies, and its majestic radiance becomes delightfully resplendent.

The *zi* and *wu* numbers combine to make three; the *wu* and *ji* numbers are called five. When three and five harmonize, the Eight Stones serve as the guiding principle. Breathing nurtures and embraces; contemplation unites them as husband and wife. Yellow earth is the father of metal; flowing pearls are the mother of water. Water relies on earth as its dam; earth restrains water from rising. The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire, balancing victory and defeat. When water prevails, fire is extinguished; when both perish, they return to the fertile earth. The three natures, once united, share a common origin.

The Eight Stones are external medicine, exemplified by the three and five. The *zi* (water) is one; the *wu* (fire) is two. The numbers of *zi* and *wu* combine to form three. Earth’s number is five, hence *wu* and *ji* are called five. When three and five harmonize, water, fire, and earth unite. These three serve as husband and wife, alternately as ruler and minister, just as the Eight Stones mutually regulate. Earth generates metal, so earth is the father of metal; earth restrains water, so earth is the dam of water. Flowing pearls are mercury, born from the sun and congealed into metal. Metal generates water, so flowing pearls are the mother of water. Watering it extinguishes fire’s flames; damming it with earth prevents water’s overflow. Thus, the three substances form one family, all returning to *wu* and *ji*. When water meets earth, it dissipates; when fire meets earth, it subsides; when metal meets earth, it returns to its father. Earth is the father of metal, so fire is the ancestor of metal—hence, when the three natures unite, their original nature shares a common ancestor.

Sesame is also called *jusheng* (great victory), an ordinary herb—consuming it can still prolong life. How much more so the divine elixir, which is the essence of pure yang? Its nature is like unbreakable vajra, and gold is the most precious treasure among all things. If one obtains and consumes it, longevity will be incomparably greater than with ordinary herbs.

The four directions—*chen*, *xu*, *chou*, and *wei*—all contain earth, showing that metal, wood, water, and fire all rely on earth to stand. Though the five viscera correspond to metal, wood, water, and fire, they ultimately depend on earth to flourish. Metal is the child of earth; when true elixir enters the abdomen and metal’s qi penetrates the five viscera, misty vapors pervade the body, steaming like the moment in smelting when fire blazes intensely and water is applied above, billowing like smoke and mist. At that time, the four limbs and hundred vessels brim with spring’s moisture, steaming and spreading naturally. The complexion is renewed, bones are transformed, old age returns to infancy, the countenance becomes radiant, the spirit joyful. White hair turns black, fallen teeth regrow in their original places, old men regain youth, and aged women become maidens. The form is altered, worldly calamities are escaped, clarity persists day and night, and consciousness remains awake. The dharma-body and illusory form are both fulfilled; yin essence and yang spirit are equally wondrous—only then can one be called a True Person.

At such a time, though mingling with the dust of the mundane, one is not of the Three Realms; though dwelling in the impure world, one’s conduct and concealment are unfathomable. If one wishes to depart, one directly ascends Penglai; if one desires to roam freely, one instantly transcends the realm of forms.

When lead powder is cast into fire, its color is destroyed and returns to lead. Ice and snow, melted by warm water, dissolve into the Great Mystery. Gold takes cinnabar as its essence, harmonizing with mercury, transforming through its truth, beginning and ending in mutual dependence. To refine and consume the immortal elixir, one must use like substances—planting millet requires millet, hatching chicks requires their own eggs, and like substances naturally assist in completion. How can fish eyes become pearls? How can mugwort become sandalwood? Like substances follow each other; discordant matters do not form treasures. Thus, swallows do not bear phoenixes; foxes and rabbits do not nurse horses. Water does not flow upward; fire does not moisten downward.

Things of like kind resonate without expectation, inevitably and without exception. Lead powder is originally lead; when burned and cast into fire again, its color is destroyed and returns to lead. Ice and snow are originally water; when warmed by fire’s qi, they return to water. The birth of the supreme treasure arises from the true essence of the Great Yang, gathering spirit and refining excellence. Initially forming cinnabar, within it already resides true mercury. When true mercury leaves its mother, it is called mercury. Mercury, in the great smelting, is refined by the Great Yang; over time, it congeals into silver. Silver, over time, transforms into gold—thus, gold fundamentally takes cinnabar as its essence. Cinnabar is spirit.

chunks.original_text: 故曰神砂汞者精也 故曰水银今者炼丹之初先采阳精变化为砂次取水银与砂相合研和二物煅炼成金既已成金方用铅养盖真精生化出乎 太阳本与太阴交合而生须得真铅始堪服食真铅生于太阴故曰同金得真铅如子得母以此相辅陶冶易成譬之以黍植禾以鸡抱卵同禀相感同炁相须也 苟不知此别求异则徒劳心力枉费工夫犹燕雀不能生狐兔不能乳马水不可以蒸物火不可以润物也 知此理则砂汞合而精神生水火交而蒸润得是火居水下而可以遂炎上之功水居火上而可以成润下之德非天下之至精其孰能与于此哉 世间多学士高妙负良才邂逅不遭遇耗火亡货财据按依文说妄以意为之端绪无因缘度量失操持捣治姜石胆云母及矾磁硫黄烧豫章泥澒相炼持鼓下五石铜以之为辅枢杂性不同种安肯合体居千举必万败欲反成痴侥幸迄不遇圣人独知之穉年至白首中道生狐疑背道守迷路出正入邪岐管窥不广见难以揆方来 金丹之理妙夺造化逈出思议之表不遇至人徒劳测度若用外物尤其狂妄守邪背正又非贤才徃徃学道之人不肯坚心寻师访友苦志勤求或有始无终或狐疑中道蹉跎白首衰老无成是皆以管窥天自高自满者之过也然明明日月荡荡乾坤寒暑徃来朝昏相代无非大道方来之理不遇至人难以揆度学者宜先积行累德以祈感遇切勿自欺到此宝山空手归去 若夫至圣不过伏羲始画八卦效法天地文王帝之宗结体演爻辞夫子庶圣雄十翼以辅之三君天所挺迭兴更御时优劣有步骤功德不相殊制作有所踵推度审分铢有形易忖量无兆难虑谋作事令可法为世定诗书素无前识资因师觉悟之皓若褰帷帐瞠目登高台 魏君天资挺特犹且因师觉悟故叹金丹妙理非有形有兆实难忖难量虽三圣寓是理于易经而八卦参机于造化象指既形之妙言彰可兆之功揆之参同犹存世法虽圣人审分铢而制作使学者探赜以推求奈何防秘辞中道超象外参同不作防昧奚明此魏君所以准穷理尽性之书述超凡入圣之道如执左契似褰前帏本出师资非干前识是知天机虽远而人人有分大道不而世世得人勿谓宿有仙骨方可希求当知但办肯心无不可者翻覆魏君前后谦辞始知前真慈悲之防 火记六百篇所趣等不殊文字郑重说世人不熟思寻度其源流幽明本共居切为贤者谈曷敢轻为书若遂结舌喑绝道获罪诛写情着竹帛又恐泄天符犹豫増叹息俛仰缀斯虑陶冶有法度未忍悉陈敷略述其纲纪枝条见扶疎 世之学者见丹经紫书火候之说述进退文武之功有始终起止之异不狐疑者鲜矣所以诸经多云有六百篇以载火候功用殊不知言殊防一体异用同既识朝屯暮之返覆则知昼姤夜复之循环如转璇玑如循轨辙虽文辞之郑重实嘱付之勤劬故彰六百篇以周三百日不出乎进退两卦但在夫始终一诚心志精专丝毫不忒叹夫圣言不世不熟思故魏君复叙三篇无非一理盖欲条析纪纲陈敷法度使后学易明厥量大哉 以金为堤防水入乃优游金计有十五水数亦如之临炉定铢两五分水有余二者以为真金重如本初其三遂不入火二与之俱三物相含受变化状若神下有太阳炁伏蒸须臾间先液而后凝号曰黄舆焉岁月将欲讫毁性伤寿年形体为灰土状若明窗尘 欲炼大丹先以纯金修筑城郭周遭围绕然后取真水入于其中始无渗漏或谓金堤或言城郭皆此意也 欲筑金堤但知四象五行全借土之理则金自然生成矣

Thus it is said: the divine cinnabar and mercury are essence. Hence, in the initial stages of refining the elixir, one first gathers the essence of Yang to transform it into cinnabar, then takes mercury to blend with the cinnabar, grinding and harmonizing the two substances. Through smelting, they are refined into gold. Only after gold is formed does one employ lead for nurturing. For true essence arises from transformation, born of the Great Yang, yet must unite with the Great Yin to generate life—only with true lead can it be fit for ingestion. True lead is born of the Great Yin, thus it is said: like substances resonate; gold, when united with true lead, is as a child returning to its mother. Through this mutual assistance, the refining process is easily accomplished. It is like planting millet to grow grain, or a hen brooding over eggs—of like kind they resonate, of like qi they depend upon one another. Should one remain ignorant of this and seek elsewhere, one will but labor in vain, squandering effort, just as sparrows cannot hatch phoenixes, foxes cannot nurse colts, water cannot steam things, nor fire moisten them.

Grasping this principle, when cinnabar and mercury unite, spirit is born; when water and fire interact, steaming and moistening occur. Thus, fire resides below water yet achieves the work of rising flame; water resides above fire yet fulfills the virtue of descending moisture. If not for the utmost essence under heaven, who could attain this? Many scholars in the world, though learned and ingenious, possessing fine talents, meet no opportunity. They exhaust fire and waste wealth, relying on texts and following them blindly, fabricating methods without foundation, losing measure and control. They pound and treat ginger stone, chalcanthite, mica, alum, magnetite, sulfur, and burn cedar clay, mixing them with the Five Minerals and copper, using these as aids. Yet their natures differ, their kinds do not align—how could they ever unite as one? A thousand attempts lead to ten thousand failures. Seeking success, they instead become deluded; hoping for fortune, they never encounter the sagely way. Alone, the sage understands. From youth to white-haired age, they waver midway, abandoning the Dao to cling to delusion, straying from the correct path into error. Their vision narrow as a tube, their knowledge too limited to fathom what lies ahead.

The principle of the golden elixir surpasses creation, far beyond the reach of thought. Without encountering a perfected one, all measurement is futile. To employ external substances is even more reckless—clinging to the heterodox while forsaking the orthodox is no path for the worthy. Yet those who often study the Dao are unwilling to steadfastly seek teachers and friends, to endure hardship and diligently inquire. Some begin but do not persist; others waver midway, wasting years until old age, achieving nothing. All this stems from the error of those who, peering at the sky through a tube, remain self-satisfied.

Yet the sun and moon shine brightly, the heavens and earth vast; cold and heat come and go, morning and evening alternate—all embody the principle of the Great Dao’s cyclic return. Without encountering a perfected one, it is difficult to fathom. Scholars should first accumulate deeds and amass virtue to invoke such an encounter, never deceiving themselves, lest they reach this mountain of treasure only to return empty-handed.

As for the utmost sages, none surpass Fuxi, who first drew the Eight Trigrams, modeling them on heaven and earth. King Wen, the ancestor of emperors, structured their forms and composed the line statements; the Master, among the host of sages, crafted the Ten Wings to assist them. These three lords, heaven-endowed, arose in succession to govern their times. Though their steps varied in excellence, their merits and virtues did not differ. Their creations built upon one another, their measurements precise to the fraction. What has form is easy to contemplate; what lacks omen is difficult to ponder. Their works became models for the world, establishing the *Book of Poetry* and *Book of Documents*, though these lacked prior knowledge, relying instead on teachers to awaken. Bright as lifting the curtain, wide-eyed as ascending a high tower.

Master Wei, though endowed with exceptional natural talent, still relied on a teacher for awakening. Thus he sighed: the wondrous principle of the golden elixir, having neither form nor omen, is truly difficult to contemplate or measure. Though the Three Sages embedded this principle in the *Book of Changes*, and the Eight Trigrams encompass the subtle workings of creation, their images point to the marvels of form, their words reveal the portents of function. Measured against the *Cantong Qi*, they still adhere to worldly methods. Though the sages weighed fractions and crafted their works for scholars to explore the profound and infer the obscure, how could they guard secrets within their words, transcending images midway? If the *Cantong Qi* had not been composed, how could this obscurity be illuminated? Thus, Master Wei, following books that exhaust principle and fulfill nature, described the way of transcending the mundane to enter sageliness—like holding the left tally, like lifting the front curtain. This arose from the transmission of teacher and disciple, not from prior knowledge. Know then that though heavenly mechanisms are distant, every person has a share; though the Great Dao is profound, every generation finds its inheritor. Do not say that only those with innate immortal bones may aspire to it. Know rather that with but a willing heart, none is unattainable. Master Wei’s humble words, both before and after, reveal the true compassion of past immortals.

The *Fire Record of Six Hundred Chapters* pursues the same aim, though its texts differ. Its words are earnest, yet people do not ponder deeply to trace its source and flow, though the obscure and manifest originally dwell together. How could I, speaking for the worthy, dare to treat it lightly? Yet if I were to seal my lips and silence the Dao, I would incur blame; to inscribe my thoughts on bamboo and silk would risk leaking heavenly secrets. Hesitating, I sigh, looking up and down, weaving these considerations. Though the methods of refining have their rules, I cannot bear to reveal them all. Thus, I briefly outline their essentials, their branches and leaves appearing in scattered form.

Scholars of the world, seeing the alchemical classics’ discussions of purple writings, fire phases, and the progression of advancing and retreating, civil and martial functions—each with its beginning and end, rise and cessation—are rarely without doubt. Hence, many texts state there are six hundred chapters to encompass the functions of fire phases. Yet they do not know that though the words differ, the substance is one; though the uses vary, the essence is the same. Once one recognizes the reversal of morning *zhun* and evening *wei*, one understands the cyclical return of day *gou* and night *fu*—like the turning of the celestial sphere, like following wheel tracks. Though the words are earnest, they are but diligent admonitions. Thus, six hundred chapters encompass three hundred days, never departing from the two trigrams of advance and retreat. All lies in the sincerity of beginning and end, the single-mindedness of intent, precise to the finest thread.

Alas! The sagely words are not obscure, yet the world does not ponder deeply. Thus, Master Wei composed three additional chapters, all embodying the same principle. He sought to clarify the essentials, expound the methods, and make the path easy for later learners to understand. How vast!

Use gold as a dike, and water enters to flow freely. Gold accounts for fifteen, and water’s number is the same. When tending the furnace, fix the weights and measures: five parts water, with two parts surplus. These two are true gold, heavy as the original. The remaining three do not enter the fire but accompany them. The three substances mutually contain and receive, transforming as if by magic. Below, the qi of the Great Yang lies hidden, steaming. In an instant, it first liquefies, then congeals—this is called the Yellow Chariot. As months and years pass, it nears decay, harming longevity. The body becomes like dust in a bright window.

To refine the great elixir, first use pure gold to construct the city walls, encircling them completely. Then take true water and place it within, so that no seepage occurs. Some call it the golden dike, others the city walls—both express this idea.

To build the golden dike, merely understand the principle that the Four Images and Five Phases fully rely on earth, and gold will naturally form.

Mercury, in the great smelting, is refined by the Great Yang; over time, it congeals into silver. Silver, over time, transforms into gold—thus, gold fundamentally takes cinnabar as its essence. Cinnabar is spirit.

chunks.original_text: 防用五行真土能成五行真金盖土者金母也 既成五行真金则能柜五行真水盖水者金子也 水土金三物纽结成方土之形而婴儿现象于其间矣 及夫运用上升则金光满室腾腾若车舆之行故号黄舆也 但临炉定则金重不过五分放水多些小不妨其三不入火二与俱者木三火二也 火二与木三俱不入如人之魂神本自无体寓物而现修真之功但炼水土金三物三物既结就而成宝则魂神自然与之俱妙矣 水入金堤本是凝液借太阳在下之气伏蒸煅炼变成黄舆火力既周神功既足则千变万化辇龙车皆是物也 及乎 脱胎则形体闪烁如明窗日影射尘之状此魏君显露功成变化之象奈何世人不知妄行忖测曾未梦见敢肆臆说惟亲诣者能知之耳 捣治并合之驰入赤色门固塞其际防务令致完坚炎火张于下昼夜声正勤始文使可修终竟武乃陈候视加勤慎审察调寒温周旋十二节节尽更相亲气索命将绝体死亡魄魂色转更为紫赫然成还丹粉提以一九刀圭最为神 此言运用之功动天地之槖钥如捣而治之直至南方赤门方固闭而使水火际防此功昼夜不绝先以文升次以武降周旋十二时一日既终更宜相亲至于炁已索然命将垂绝百脉归根万窍俱寂非死也犹死也绝后重苏金光转紫状如紫粉一刀圭许时时呈露处处见形变化不测神妙不可思议矣 推演五行数较约而不烦举水以激火奄然灭光明日月相激薄常在晦朔间水盛坎侵阳火衰离昼昏阴阳相饮食交感道自然 若以五行较之火见水则奄然灭光然日月亦水火也毎遇合朔两不相伤何也盖天地阴阳交感相食自有定数定期无水盛火衰之害能察其机而盗用之则宇宙在手万化在身虽水火之相克而合为夫妇金木之间隔而自然交通然天下莫能见而莫能知也悲夫 名者以定情字者缘性言金来归性初乃得称还丹吾不敢虚说仿效圣人文古记题龙虎黄帝美金华淮南炼秋石王阳加黄芽贤者能持行不肖毋与俱古今道由一对谈吐所谋学者加勉力留念深思惟至要言甚露昭昭不我欺 此言还丹之所以称还丹也还者以情言丹者以性言金来归性初者言金公本我性所生今使之复见其母还归本初与姹女相合结成婴儿故曰还丹紫阳诗曰金公本是东家子送在西林寄体生认得唤来归舍养配将姹女结亲情是也古今名称虽不同其实一道也 周易参同契解卷上 <子部,道家类,周易参同契解>

To employ the true earth of the Five Phases is to perfect the true gold of the Five Phases—earth being the mother of metal. Once the true gold of the Five Phases is achieved, it can then contain the true water of the Five Phases—water being the child of metal. Water, earth, and metal intertwine to form a square shape of earth, within which the infant appears. When activated and ascending, the golden light fills the chamber, billowing like a chariot in motion—hence the name "Yellow Chariot."

When tending the furnace, ensure the weight of gold does not exceed five fen, allowing the water to be slightly more abundant. The three that do not enter the fire—two accompanying them—are wood (three) and fire (two). Fire (two) and wood (three) do not enter, much like the soul and spirit, which are inherently formless yet manifest through things. The work of true refinement lies in refining the three substances: water, earth, and metal. Once these three coalesce and form the treasure, the soul and spirit naturally accompany them in wondrous union.

Water enters the golden dike, originally a congealed liquid, steamed and refined by the hidden qi of the Great Yang below. Once the fire’s power is complete and the divine work fulfilled, it transforms into the Yellow Chariot, capable of myriad changes—whether as a dragon-drawn carriage or any other form. Upon shedding its embryo, the body shimmers like dust illuminated by sunlight through a bright window, revealing the accomplished transformations of Master Wei. Yet how can the world know? Those who recklessly speculate have never glimpsed even a dream of it, daring to voice their conjectures. Only those who have personally witnessed it can understand.

In the process of pounding, blending, and merging, enter the Crimson Gate, sealing its borders to ensure firmness. Ignite the blazing fire below, maintaining it day and night with unwavering diligence. Begin with the civil (wen) and conclude with the martial (wu), observing and adjusting with care. Monitor the cold and warmth, cycling through the twelve nodes, each completing its turn in mutual intimacy. When qi is nearly exhausted and life on the verge of cessation, the body approaches death—yet the hun and po transform, their hues shifting to a radiant purple, forming the Reverted Elixir. Powdered and measured with a ninefold knife’s edge, it is most divine.

This speaks of the work’s power, moving the bellows of heaven and earth. Pound and refine it until reaching the southern Crimson Gate, firmly sealing the boundary between water and fire. This labor continues day and night: first ascending with wen, then descending with wu, cycling through the twelve hours. As the day ends, they should grow ever closer. When qi is nearly spent and life hangs by a thread, the hundred vessels return to their root, and the myriad orifices fall silent—not death, yet akin to it. After this cessation, revival occurs: the golden light turns purple, resembling purple powder, a mere knife’s edge in quantity, manifesting everywhere in unfathomable transformations of divine wonder.

Expounding the numbers of the Five Phases, the method is concise yet not cumbersome: use water to stimulate fire, and its light is suddenly extinguished. Yet the sun and moon, too, are water and fire. At each conjunction, they do not harm one another—why? Because the mutual consumption of heaven and earth’s yin and yang follows a fixed pattern, a set rhythm. There is no harm in water’s dominance or fire’s decline. Those who perceive this mechanism and steal its use hold the cosmos in their hands and the myriad transformations within their bodies. Though water and fire are mutually destructive, they unite as husband and wife; though metal and wood are separated, they naturally communicate. Yet none in the world can see or know this—how lamentable!

The name defines the essence, while the term arises from nature. When metal returns to its original nature, it is called the Reverted Elixir. I dare not speak falsely, for I emulate the sages: the ancient texts speak of the Dragon and Tiger, the Yellow Emperor’s praise of Golden Flowers, Huainan’s refinement of Autumn Stone, and Wang Yang’s addition of Yellow Sprouts. The worthy may practice this, but the unworthy should not partake. The Dao of past and present arises from a single pair—let scholars exert effort, reflect deeply, and ponder its utmost importance. The words are clear and luminous, never deceiving me.

This explains why the Reverted Elixir is so named: "revert" refers to essence, "elixir" to nature. "Metal returns to its original nature" means that Metal Elder, born of my nature, now returns to its mother, reuniting with its origin. Together with the Maiden, it forms the infant—hence the Reverted Elixir. As the poem by Master Purple Yang says: *"Metal Elder was originally the Eastern House’s child, sent to the Western Grove to lodge. Once recognized, call it home to nurture, betroth it to the Maiden, and unite in affection."* Though ancient and modern names differ, the Dao remains one.

chunks.original_text: 钦定四库全书 周易参同契解卷中 宋　陈显微　撰 中篇 干刚坤柔配合相包阳禀阴受雄雌相须须以造化精炁乃舒坎离冠首光耀垂敷防难测不可画图圣人揆度参序元基四者混沌径入虚无六十卦周张布为舆龙马就驾明君御时和则随从路平不邪邪道险阻倾危国家 乾坤刚柔二者配合递相包含则自然阳禀与而阴受藏也 盖阳雄则播施阴雌则含受孤阳不生孤阴不育雄雌二者相须精炁舒布以成造化如人受胎莫不以阴阳相交为之造化故当以乾坤二卦为始今云坎离冠首者盖乾坤为天地坎离为日月天地定位不能合而为一而交于其中合而为一者日月也 故乾坤为药之体坎离为药之用所以只言坎离冠首者以明大药之用全在坎离也 是则乾坤为鼎而坎离为药尔然坎离之用即于乾坤二体之间上下徃来飞潜不定岂易画图哉 圣人欲揆度其妙以告学者惟观六十离坎之中一阳画一阴爻或在上或在下防难测但当如明君之御时而以六十卦为舆泰然无为以就驾则可晏然而顺步徐徐进道雍容和易稳路平驱自始至终周循诸卦安有险阻之患故曰和则随从路平不邪苟不达此妄行邪径则有颠覆之忧倾危之咎矣 刘海蟾云莫教翻却紫河车与此意同盖言路虽平夷须防险阻不可不谨也 君子居其室出其言善则千里之外应之谓万乘之主处九重之室发号出令顺阴阳节藏器俟时勿违卦月屯以子申用寅戌余六十卦各自有日 修丹之士一年处室尤为艰难所动虽小所感甚大如万乘之君深居九重动止语默关系天和如易所谓君子居室应在千里正可为比惟当顺阴阳之降腾随行德而进止如怀至宝如获目睛如养胎儿如持满器俟时之至不可违于卦月屯则自子至申则自寅至戌其余诸卦各自有时盖一日两卦一时六爻欲识阴阳须分昼夜欲知昼夜须分黑白黑白既分卦爻斯得易曰通乎昼夜之道而知者此也 聊陈两象未能究悉立义设刑当仁设德逆之者凶顺之者吉按历法令至诚专密谨候日夜审察消息纤介不正悔吝为诚 两象者屯也未能究息者不敢尽泄火候天机也学者遇师得防依时下手结就丹头须当按乎历法至诚专密谨候日夜审察消息遇阳则进如当仁而施德遇阴则退如立义而设刑顺之者吉逆之者凶如其间毫发不正则有悔吝存乎其间而为贼害如苖中之草莱镜中之尘垢且世人炼丹砂犹恐水火差误况此金液大丹乎 二至改度乖错委曲隆冬大暑盛夏霜雪二分纵横不应漏刻风雨不节水旱相伐蝗虫涌沸群异旁出天见其怪山崩地裂孝子用心感动皇极近出已口远流殊域或以招祸或以致福或兴太平或造兵革四者之中由乎胸臆 二至者阴阳之始从出也苟乖错其用则天变随之夏雪冬雷灾异斯惨二分者阴阳之所交分也苟乖错其用则天变亦然山崩地裂水旱为灾不可胜言矣此盖运火之士失时差误而真胎损害世界崩摧孝子喻真胎皇极喻祸福或致太平或致兵革或以招祸或以招福皆由运火之士胸臆所感召也炼丹之法与世法无殊然治世之所感召犹如影响况夺天地之造化而与天地合其德同其运耶 动静有常奉其绳墨四时顺宜与气相得刚柔断矣不相涉入五行守界不妄盈缩易行周流屈伸反覆火候祸福既如前章则当动静有常如循绳墨不可差四时之宜自然与二炁相得刚不侵逾柔不退缩或屈或伸或反或覆五行周流各守疆界方可无虞 晦朔之间合符行中混沌鸿蒙牝牡相从滋液润泽施化流通天地神灵不可度量利用安身形而藏始于东北箕斗之乡施而右转呕轮吐萌潜潭见象发散精光
chunks.translated_text:
The *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Explication of the Union of the Three in Accordance with the Book of Changes*, Scroll Middle
By Chen Xianwei of the Song Dynasty

**Middle Scroll**

The firmness of Qian and the softness of Kun pair and envelop one another; yang endows while yin receives. Male and female depend on each other, and only then do essence and qi unfold to bring forth creation. Kan and Li crown the head, their radiance shining forth. Their profundity is difficult to fathom, and they cannot be depicted in diagrams. The sage measures and weighs, arranging the primordial foundation. The four are merged in primordial chaos, entering directly into the formless. The sixty hexagrams spread forth like a chariot’s canopy. The dragon-horse is harnessed, and the enlightened ruler takes the reins. When harmony prevails, one follows the level path; if not, the Way becomes perilous, the state topples, and the nation falls into danger.

The firmness of Qian and the softness of Kun—these two pair and alternately envelop one another, so that yang naturally endows while yin receives and conceals. For yang, being male, scatters and bestows, while yin, being female, contains and receives. Solitary yang does not generate; solitary yin does not nurture. Only when male and female depend on each other do essence and qi unfold and spread to complete creation. Just as the conception of a child invariably arises from the union of yin and yang, so too must Qian and Kun be taken as the beginning. Now, it is said that Kan and Li crown the head because Qian and Kun are Heaven and Earth, while Kan and Li are the Sun and Moon. Heaven and Earth, though fixed in position, cannot merge into one, yet within them, the Sun and Moon unite as one. Thus, Qian and Kun are the body of the medicine, while Kan and Li are its function. The reason only Kan and Li are said to crown the head is to clarify that the function of the great medicine lies entirely in Kan and Li. Therefore, Qian and Kun serve as the crucible, while Kan and Li serve as the medicine. Yet the function of Kan and Li operates between the two bodies of Qian and Kun, ascending and descending, flying and submerging without fixed form—how could this be easily depicted in diagrams?

The sage, wishing to measure and weigh its profound subtleties to instruct scholars, observes only the sixty hexagrams of Li and Kan, where one yang line and one yin line, sometimes above and sometimes below, are difficult to fathom. One must act like an enlightened ruler governing the times, taking the sixty hexagrams as a chariot and proceeding with effortless action to harness the dragon-horse. Then one may advance leisurely and steadily, progressing along the Way with grace and ease, the path smooth and unobstructed from beginning to end, cycling through all the hexagrams. How could there be peril or obstruction? Thus it is said: "When harmony prevails, one follows the level path, free from deviation." If one fails to grasp this and recklessly follows a deviant path, there will be the worry of collapse and the fault of danger.

Liu Haichan said, *"Do not let the Purple Cart overturn,"* which conveys the same meaning—though the path may be smooth, one must guard against peril and cannot be careless.

The noble person, dwelling in their chamber, speaks good words, and a thousand *li* away, they are answered. This is like the lord of ten thousand chariots, abiding in the innermost chamber, issuing decrees and commands in accordance with the rhythms of yin and yang, storing instruments and awaiting the proper time, never violating the hexagrams and months. *Zhun* begins at *zi*, and *Meng* at *yin*; the remaining sixty hexagrams each have their own days.

For those who cultivate the elixir, residing in seclusion for a year is especially arduous. Even the slightest movement has profound effects, like the lord of ten thousand chariots dwelling deep within the ninefold palace, where every action, stillness, word, and silence affects the harmony of Heaven. As the *Book of Changes* says, *"The noble person dwells in their chamber, yet their influence extends a thousand *li*,"* which serves as an apt comparison. One must follow the ascent and descent of yin and yang, advancing and halting in accordance with virtue, cherishing the treasure as if it were one’s eyes, nurturing the embryo as if holding a full vessel, awaiting the arrival of the proper time, never violating the hexagrams and months. *Zhun* spans from *zi* to *shen*, and *Meng* from *yin* to *xu*. The remaining hexagrams each have their own times, for each day comprises two hexagrams, and each hour, six lines. To discern yin and yang, one must distinguish day and night; to know day and night, one must distinguish light and dark. Once light and dark are distinguished, the hexagrams and lines are understood. As the *Book of Changes* says, *"One who understands the Way of day and night knows this."*

I have briefly presented the two images, though I have not fully exhausted their subtleties. Establishing principles and setting punishments, acting with benevolence and virtue—those who go against these meet misfortune, while those who follow them meet good fortune. According to the calendar, one must be sincere, focused, and meticulous, observing day and night, scrutinizing the ebb and flow. Even the slightest deviation brings regret and adversity.

The two images refer to *Zhun* and *Meng*. Not fully exhausting their subtleties means I dare not reveal the celestial mechanics of the fire times. When a scholar encounters a teacher and receives the method, they must act in accordance with the calendar, being sincere, focused, and meticulous, observing day and night, scrutinizing the ebb and flow. When yang arises, advance as if acting with benevolence and virtue; when yin arises, retreat as if establishing principles and setting punishments. Those who follow meet good fortune; those who go against meet misfortune. If even the slightest deviation occurs, regret and adversity arise within, becoming thieves and harm. Like weeds in a field or dust on a mirror, even those who refine cinnabar fear errors in water and fire—how much more so for this great elixir of golden liquid?

At the two solstices, the measures change, and if they go awry, complications arise. In the depths of winter, scorching heat; in the height of summer, frost and snow. At the two equinoxes, the directions are askew, the clepsydra’s flow unregulated, wind and rain untimely, floods and droughts contending, locusts swarming, and myriad anomalies emerging. Heaven displays its omens, mountains collapse, and the earth splits. The filial son’s sincerity moves the August Ultimate, bringing near what was uttered and spreading afar what was distant, sometimes inviting misfortune, sometimes bringing fortune, sometimes ushering in great peace, sometimes inciting war. These four outcomes arise from the heart’s intentions.

The two solstices mark the beginning of yin and yang. If their function goes awry, celestial anomalies follow—snow in summer, thunder in winter, and calamities arise. The two equinoxes are where yin and yang intersect. If their function goes awry, celestial anomalies likewise follow—mountains collapsing, the earth splitting, floods and droughts causing endless disasters. This occurs because those who regulate the fire lose the proper time, causing the true embryo to be harmed and the world to crumble. The filial son symbolizes the true embryo, and the August Ultimate symbolizes fortune and misfortune. Whether great peace or war arises, whether fortune or misfortune is invited, all stem from the intentions of those who regulate the fire. The method of refining the elixir is no different from the methods of the world. Yet the responses to governing the world are like echoes and shadows—how much more so when seizing the creation of Heaven and Earth, aligning one’s virtue with Heaven and Earth and synchronizing one’s movements with them?

Movement and stillness have their constancy; one must adhere to the marking line. The four seasons proceed in harmony, aligning with qi. Firmness and softness are decisively distinguished, not intruding upon one another. The Five Phases each guard their boundaries, not recklessly expanding or contracting. The *Book of Changes* flows and circulates, bending and stretching, reversing and turning. As for the fire times and fortune and misfortune, as previously discussed, one must maintain constancy in movement and stillness, following the marking line without deviation. The four seasons proceed in harmony, naturally aligning with the two qi. Firmness does not overstep, and softness does not retreat. Whether bending or stretching, reversing or turning, the Five Phases circulate, each guarding their boundaries—only then can one be free from worry.

Between the dark and new moons, the tally is joined, and primordial chaos merges with the vast expanse. The female and male follow one another, their fluids moistening and nourishing, their transformations flowing and circulating. The spirits of Heaven and Earth cannot be measured. Utilizing them, one secures the body, concealing the form and hiding it. It begins in the northeast, in the region of *Ji* and *Dou*, then moves rightward, spewing forth the wheel and spitting out the sprout. Hidden in the deep pool, an image appears, scattering its essence and light.

chunks.original_text: 至于晦朔之间则当合符行中如混沌鸿蒙不可度量盖牝牡相从滋液润泽施化流通之时也岂可用工乎故利用安身形而藏却自箕斗之乡呕轮吐萌发散精光可也寒山子诗云不得露其根根子自坠盖体用不同施功亦异故也 昴毕之上震出为微阳气造端初九潜龙阳以三立阴以八通故三日震动八日兑行九三见龙和平有明二五德就干体乃成九三夕惕亏折神符盛衰【阙】革终还其初巽继其统固济操持九四或跃进退道危艮主进止不得逾时二十三日典守期九五飞龙天位加喜六五坤承结括终始韫养众子世为母上九亢龙下德于野用九翩翩为道规矩阳数已讫讫则复起推情合性转而相与 魏君以一月之间月形圆缺喻卦象进退自初三日为一阳初八日为二阳十五则三阳全而干体就十六则一阴生二十三则二阴生三十日则三阴全而坤体成昴毕在西方庚位如上卷所言震庚见西方之意相同余备述于前卷魏君重复言之欲学人深明体用耳 循据璇玑升降上下周流六爻难可察睹故无常位为易宗祖 一日之间火候周旋如璇玑之运自子升上至午降下周历六爻虽无形迹可观而默运造化防之于心其时灵药随日徃来升降上下未尝停止岂有常位所以与大易阳生阴降之理合也谓为易宗祖者圣人先吾金丹之理以自修持超凡入圣而后述是理于易以示后人是知大易之作本诸大丹而大丹之道乃易之宗祖也 朔旦为复阳气始通出入无疾立表微刚黄钟建子兆乃滋彰播施柔暖黎蒸得常 半夜子时火候起绪也一阳未生火候未动众阴群居如众庶无统及乎火候既动阳炁始通播施和暖熏蒸鼎器光明既兆则为万化发生之主是时修炼之士便能默防进火之机以微刚为表准出入徃来收放无疾自滋以徃渐渐増修以至纯乾坤炼成宝大凡初功尤宜加谨前辈诗云夜寒宜向火防众到天明此即播施柔暖黎蒸得常之义也 临炉施条开路正光光曜渐进日以益长丑之大吕结正低昂 丑时进二阳火候也至是则光耀渐进开路正光明也阳自下生当就下结其时用功正低待过此一爻渐以放仰以随化机故曰结正低昂 仰以成泰刚柔并隆阴阳交接小往大来辐辏于寅运而趋时 寅时进三阳火候也至是则刚柔交分阴阳各半上水下火是则精水上腾神火下仰仰者欲升腾者欲降阴阳交接小徃大来造化辐辏于此 渐历大壮侠列卯门榆荚堕落还归本根刑德相负昼夜始分 卯时进四阳沐浴之候也其时昼夜始分生杀相半万物至春敷荣而榆荚至是独落盖榆荚应星星至晓以金丹与森罗万象相参而万象森罗亦生于日月故也 夬阴以退阳升而前洗濯羽翮振索宿尘 辰时进五阳火候也至是则五阳上升水源清澄如禽出水振洗羽翼将欲奋飞为冲天之举矣 干健盛明广被四邻阳终于已中而神盈 巳时进六阳火候也至是则纯干体就月圆水满光盛神盈正而不偏圆而不缺光被四表明遍十方矣 姤始纪绪履霜最先井底寒泉午为防宾宾伏于阴阴为主人 午时退一阴符候也至是则阴为主而阳为客苟不识主中宾宾中主则差之毫为害不细勿以一阴方萌未能为害奈何井底寒泉而履霜冰至前辈所以切切论宾主之分者以此 遁世去位收敛其精懐德俟时栖迟昧防 未时退二阴符候也 否塞不通萌者不生阴伸阳屈没阳姓名 申时退三阴符候也 观其权量察仲秋情任蓄微稚老枯复荣荠麦芽蘖因冒以生

Between the dark and new moons, one must join the tally and move within the center, like primordial chaos merging with the vast expanse—beyond measure. This is the time when the female and male follow one another, their fluids moistening and nourishing, their transformations flowing and circulating. How could one apply effort here? Thus, by utilizing them, one secures the body, concealing the form and hiding it. It begins in the northeast, in the region of *Ji* and *Dou*, then moves rightward, spewing forth the wheel and spitting out the sprout, scattering its essence and light. As the poem by Hanshanzi says: *"Do not expose the root, for the root will naturally fall."* The body and its function differ, and so too does the application of effort.

Above *Mao* and *Bi*, *Zhen* emerges as the faint yang qi begins its inception. In the *First Nine*, the hidden dragon lies low; yang is established by three, and yin is connected by eight. Thus, on the third day, *Zhen* stirs; on the eighth day, *Dui* moves. In the *Nine in the Third*, the dragon appears in the field, harmonious and luminous. The *Second* and *Fifth* virtues align, and the *Qian* body is complete. In the *Nine in the Third*, vigilance at dusk brings loss and decline to the spirit tally—its rise and fall are cut short, returning to its origin. *Xun* continues the lineage, firmly holding fast. In the *Nine in the Fourth*, one may leap forward or retreat, the Way perilous. *Gen* governs advance and cessation, not to be transgressed in time. On the twenty-third day, one guards the appointed term. In the *Nine in the Fifth*, the flying dragon ascends to the celestial position, adding joy. In the *Six in the Fifth*, *Kun* bears and binds, completing the cycle, nurturing all beings as the eternal mother. In the *Nine at the Top*, the dragon soars too high, its virtue cast into the wilds. With *Use the Nine*, it flutters as the Dao’s compass and square. When yang’s numbers are exhausted, they begin anew, turning to align with nature and unite with inherent qualities.

Wei Jun illustrates the waxing and waning of the moon within a month, likening it to the hexagrams’ advance and retreat: from the third day, the first yang arises; by the eighth day, the second yang; by the fifteenth, the third yang is complete, and the *Qian* body is formed. On the sixteenth, the first yin is born; by the twenty-third, the second yin; by the thirtieth, the third yin is complete, and the *Kun* body is perfected. *Mao* and *Bi* reside in the west, in the position of *Geng*, as mentioned in the previous volume. *Zhen* and *Geng* appearing in the west share the same meaning, as previously described in detail. Wei Jun repeats this to deepen the learner’s understanding of body and function.

Following the turning of the celestial pivot, ascending and descending, rising and falling, the six lines circulate in a cycle difficult to perceive—thus, they have no fixed position, becoming the ancestral source of the *Yi*. Within a single day, the fire phases revolve like the turning of the celestial pivot: from *Zi*, ascending to *Wu*, then descending, traversing the six lines. Though no visible traces can be observed, the subtle workings of creation are guarded in the heart. At these times, the elixir medicine arrives with the sun, ascending and descending, rising and falling without cease—never occupying a fixed position. This aligns with the *Great Yi*’s principle of yang ascending and yin descending. That it is called the ancestral source of the *Yi* means the sages first grasped the principle of golden elixir through self-cultivation, transcending the mundane to attain sagehood, and only afterward expounded this principle in the *Yi* to instruct later generations. Thus, the *Great Yi* was created based on the great elixir, and the Way of the great elixir is the ancestral source of the *Yi*.

At the dawn of the new moon, *Fu* arises, and yang qi begins to flow, entering and exiting without haste. Erect a subtle marker of firmness: the *Yellow Bell* is established in *Zi*, its signs flourishing, spreading warmth and gentle steam, allowing the common people to thrive in constancy. At midnight, the *Zi* hour, the fire phase begins its work. Before the first yang arises, the fire phase remains still, and the multitude of yin gathers like the masses without governance. Once the fire phase stirs, yang qi begins to flow, spreading warmth and gentle steam, suffusing the cauldron with radiance. When the first signs appear, it becomes the master of all transformations. At this time, the cultivator must silently guard the mechanism of advancing the fire, using subtle firmness as the standard. Entering and exiting, coming and going, gathering and releasing proceed without haste, naturally nourishing and gradually increasing until pure *Qian* and *Kun* refine the precious treasure. In the initial stages, one must be especially cautious. As the ancients’ poem says: *"On cold nights, tend the fire; guard against the crowd until dawn."* This embodies the meaning of *"spreading warmth and gentle steam, allowing the common people to thrive in constancy."*

In *Lin*, the furnace is tended, the path opened, and the radiance gradually advances, growing day by day. In *Chou*, the *Great Lü* is established, its structure rising and falling. At the *Chou* hour, the second yang fire phase advances. By this time, the radiance gradually increases, opening the mysterious path and illuminating the true light. Yang arises from below, so one must bind it there. At this stage, the work is lowly; after passing this line, one gradually lifts and follows the transformative mechanism—thus, *"its structure rises and falling."*

Raising it forms *Tai*, where firmness and softness flourish together, yin and yang intertwine, the small departs and the great arrives, converging in *Yin* and advancing with the season. At the *Yin* hour, the third yang fire phase advances. By this time, firmness and softness are distinct, yin and yang each half. Above is water, below is fire—essence-water ascends, spirit-fire descends. The ascending seeks to rise, the descending seeks to fall; yin and yang intertwine, the small departs and the great arrives, and creation converges here.

Gradually progressing through *Dazhuang*, arrayed at the *Mao* gate, the elm pods fall and return to their root. Punishment and virtue contend, and day and night begin to divide. At the *Mao* hour, the fourth yang undergoes the bathing phase. At this time, day and night divide, life and death are balanced, and all things flourish in spring—yet the elm pods alone fall. This is because the elm pods correspond to the stars, and by dawn, they wither. The golden elixir parallels the myriad phenomena, and all phenomena arise from the sun and moon.

In *Guai*, yin retreats as yang ascends, washing and cleansing the wings, shaking off the dust of the roost. At the *Chen* hour, the fifth yang fire phase advances. By this time, the fifth yang ascends, and the water source is clear and limpid, like a bird emerging from water, shaking its wings, preparing to soar into the heavens.

In *Qian*, vigor flourishes, its brightness spreading to the four neighbors. Yang culminates in the center of *Si*, and the spirit is full. At the *Si* hour, the sixth yang fire phase advances. By this time, the pure *Qian* body is complete, the moon full, the water abundant, the light flourishing, and the spirit full—upright yet not biased, round yet not lacking, its radiance spreading to the four directions, illuminating all ten directions.

In *Gou*, the beginning is recorded, treading frost first, like the cold spring at the well’s bottom. *Wu* guards the guest, the guest concealed within yin, yin as the host. At the *Wu* hour, the first yin tally retreats. By this time, yin is the host and yang the guest. If one fails to recognize the host within the guest and the guest within the host, the slightest deviation brings great harm. Do not dismiss the first yin as harmless—like treading frost, ice will soon follow. The ancients’ urgent emphasis on distinguishing host and guest stems from this.

In *Dun*, the world is abandoned, the position relinquished, essence gathered, and virtue cherished, awaiting the time to rest in obscurity. At the *Wei* hour, the second yin tally retreats.

In *Pi*, obstruction prevails, and what sprouts cannot grow. Yin extends, yang withdraws, and yang’s name is erased. At the *Shen* hour, the third yin tally retreats.

In *Guan*, its authority and measure are observed. In mid-autumn, the emotions of the season are entrusted to the stored, the tender and the old, the withered and the flourishing. Shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout anew, growing beneath the cover.

chunks.original_text: 酉时退四阴符沐浴候也荠麦应日故至八月芽蘖日魂胎于酉也木至是而胎藏土至是而沐浴故酉为沐浴之候 剥烂肢体消灭其形化气既竭亡失至神 戌时退五阴符候也 道穷则返归乎坤元怛顺地理承天布宣 亥时退六阴符候也 幽远隔阂相连应度育种阴阳之源寥廓恍惚莫知其端先迷失轨后为主君无平主陂道之自然变易更盛消息相应终坤始复如循连环帝王乘御千载常存 磁石吸铁阳燧取火方诸取水皆阴阳相感隔碍相通之理岂能测其端倪哉修丹之功始若迷分及乎 火候既终丹力既熟方知【阙】　　　　　　之乘御矣此道岂外乎终坤始复之机哉魏君三复言之可谓明之尽矣 将欲养性延命却期审思后来当虑其先人所禀躯体本一无元精云布因炁托初 夫血气之属各有性而性未尝不出于正也血气之属各有命而命未尝不出于情也然性本正矣及乎迷失真性而沦溺于邪蹊甚至为凶人为蛇为蝎为异变其性而为邪性者有矣命本情矣及乎明心见性了知一切众生各因淫欲而正斯命于是炼精化炁入圣超凡变其命而为正命者有矣知性之本然后能养知命之正然后能延试思夫人之始初禀受形躯之时本一正性也而父母交精元气云布果出于正耶果出于情耶圆觉经谓命因欲有与此同防 阴阳为度魂魄所居阳神日魂阴神月魄魂之与魄互为宅舍性主处内立置鄞鄂情主营外筑垣城廓城廓完全人物乃安爰斯之时情合乾坤干动而直炁布精流坤静而翕为道舍庐刚施而退柔化以滋九还七返八归六居男白女赤金火相拘则水定火五行之初上善若水清而无瑕道之形象真一难图变而分布各自独居 夫情性生于魂魄魂魄生于明暗明暗生于日月日月生于阴阳圣人以乾坤刚柔动静阖辟之机推测之此大丹之道所以契大易也 其要不出乎 以阴阳为度也 故日出于卯则天明而魂盛日入于酉则天暗而魄盛魂为阳神魄为阴神魂以昼为室魄以夜为宅其实不出乎 明暗二机也 夫人昼明则用魂用神而魂体本性也 夜暗则归精归魄精魄本命也 命生情故以精魄为城郭性生心故存心神为鄞鄂城郭固坚人物乃安当斯之时以情营外然后乾坤合而刚柔动静阖辟之理得矣 于是一运之炁周乎 太空升降混沦俱化真土九金八木七火六水还返归居皆入于土矣 归土则五行全而万物生其中男见白形女呈赤色盖五行聚防而金火相拘火炼金而金柜水如汤在鼎而玉鼎汤煎如鼎在炉而金炉火炽只言水金火三者总在土中言火则自然有木造化既成铅凝汞结于鼎中则水之为功又善之上者也 至宝无瑕至真难摸火候既足五行分布则又各自独居而不相陵犯也 如鸡子黑白相扶纵广一寸以为始初四肢五脏筋骨乃俱弥历十月脱出其胞骨弱可卷肉滑若铅 纵广一寸横微狭焉 法身在其中矣前辈
chunks.translated_text:
At the *You* hour, the fourth yin tally retreats—this is the bathing phase. Shepherd’s purse and wheat respond to the sun, so by the eighth month their sprouts emerge. The sun’s essence is conceived at *You*, for wood is nurtured within at this time, and earth undergoes its bathing. Thus, *You* marks the bathing phase.

In *Bo*, the limbs rot and the form dissolves, its transformation into qi exhausted, its spirit lost.

At the *Xu* hour, the fifth yin tally retreats. When the Dao is exhausted, it returns to Kun’s primal origin. In solemn compliance with earth’s principles, it bears heaven’s mandate and spreads its decree.

At the *Hai* hour, the sixth yin tally retreats. The profound and distant, though separated by barriers, remain connected in resonance. It nurtures the seed, the source of yin and yang, vast and indistinct, its beginning unknowable. Those who lose their way first become lost, while those who follow later become masters. Without a level ruler, the Dao naturally inclines. Its transformations alternate in waxing and waning, ever responsive. From Kun’s end arises Fu’s beginning, like tracing an unbroken ring. Emperors and kings ride this principle, enduring for a thousand generations.

The magnet’s attraction of iron, the burning mirror’s capture of fire, the moon’s gathering of water—all exemplify the mutual resonance of yin and yang, their barriers transcended. How could one fathom its beginnings? In the practice of elixir refinement, one first wanders in confusion, but once the fire-tending is complete and the elixir’s power matures, one then knows the riding of [lacuna]—this Dao is nothing other than the mechanism of Kun’s end and Fu’s beginning. Master Wei repeatedly expounded this, and his clarity was exhaustive.

To cultivate nature and prolong life, one must reverse the sequence: first consider what comes later, then attend to what precedes. The body one inherits is originally undifferentiated, its primordial essence dispersed, its qi the foundation of its inception.

Blood and qi each possess their own nature, and this nature never deviates from the upright. Blood and qi each possess their own destiny, and this destiny never strays from emotion. Yet while nature is fundamentally upright, when one loses the true nature and sinks into depravity, one may become a villain, a serpent, a scorpion, or some monstrous transformation—such are those whose nature becomes perverse. While destiny is rooted in emotion, when one awakens the mind and perceives nature, understanding that all beings owe their existence to desire, one refines essence into qi, ascends to sagehood, and transcends the mundane—such are those whose destiny becomes upright.

Consider this: when a person first receives their bodily form, it is fundamentally an upright nature. Yet when parents unite in passion, is the primordial qi they disperse truly upright? Does it arise from emotion? The *Yuanjue Jing* states that destiny arises from desire—this aligns with the present discussion.

Yin and yang serve as the measure, the dwelling of hun and po. The yang spirit is the sun’s hun, the yin spirit the moon’s po. Hun and po mutually serve as abodes. Nature presides within, establishing the inner citadel; emotion operates without, constructing the outer walls. When the walls are complete, beings find peace.

At this time, emotion harmonizes with Qian and Kun. Qian moves and extends, its qi spreading, its essence flowing. Kun is still and receptive, becoming the Dao’s dwelling. The firm acts and retreats; the yielding transforms and nourishes. Nine returns, seven reversions, eight returns, six residences—male appears white, female appears red. Metal and fire restrain each other, then water settles. Fire, the first of the five phases, is supremely good like water—clear and flawless. The Dao’s form resembles the True One, difficult to depict. Though it transforms and disperses, each phase dwells in its own place.

Emotion and nature arise from hun and po; hun and po arise from light and darkness; light and darkness arise from the sun and moon; the sun and moon arise from yin and yang. The sage infers this from Qian and Kun’s firmness and yielding, movement and stillness, opening and closing—thus the Great Elixir’s Dao accords with the *Great Change*. Its essence lies in nothing other than yin and yang as the measure.

Thus, when the sun rises at *Mao*, the sky brightens and hun flourishes. When the sun sets at *You*, the sky darkens and po flourishes. Hun is the yang spirit, po the yin spirit. Hun’s chamber is day, po’s dwelling is night—yet in truth, they do not transcend the two mechanisms of light and darkness.

When people are awake in daylight, they employ hun and spirit, for hun’s essence is nature. When night falls, they return to essence and po, for essence and po are destiny. Destiny generates emotion, so essence and po become the outer walls. Nature generates the mind, so preserving the mind’s spirit becomes the inner citadel. When the walls are firm, beings find peace. At this time, when emotion operates externally, Qian and Kun unite, and the principles of firmness and yielding, movement and stillness, opening and closing are realized.

Then, a single circulation of qi pervades the great void. Ascending and descending, all is transformed in undifferentiated chaos. The true earth, nine metals, eight woods, seven fires, six waters—all return and reside, each entering into earth. When they return to earth, the five phases are complete, and the myriad things are born within it. The male appears in white form, the female in red hue. The five phases gather and restrain one another: metal and fire contend, fire smelts metal, and metal encases water like boiling soup in a cauldron. The cauldron is heated in the furnace, and the metal furnace blazes. Here, water, metal, and fire are all within earth. Where there is fire, wood naturally exists. Once the transformations are complete, lead congeals and mercury coalesces within the crucible—then water’s function is the highest good.

The supreme treasure is flawless; the utmost reality is difficult to grasp. When the fire-tending is sufficient and the five phases disperse, each dwells in its own place without encroachment.

Like a chicken’s egg, black and white support each other, its length and breadth a single inch—this is the beginning. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones all develop within. After ten months, it emerges from the womb, its bones pliable enough to coil, its flesh smooth as lead. Its length is an inch, its width slightly narrower. The Dharma-body resides within. The ancients...

In *Pi*, obstruction prevails, and what sprouts cannot grow. Yin extends, yang withdraws, and yang’s name is erased. At the *Shen* hour, the third yin tally retreats.

chunks.original_text: 有云争如跳出珠光 内踊身直到紫微宫 阳燧以取火非日不生光方诸非星月安能得水浆二炁且远感化尚相通何况近存身切在于心胸阴阳配日月水火为效征 阳燧者炼五色石作镜向日以艾取火淮南子谓之火方诸又有水方诸以水晶为珠向月取火又谓之阴燧阳燧方诸若不假日月则不能生水取火人身之中阴阳升降与天地造化同运其间水火交通之理亦岂外乎日月徃来之机以求证效哉 耳目口三宝固塞勿发通真人潜深渊浮游守规中旋曲以视听开阖皆合同为已之枢辖动静不竭穷离炁内营卫坎乃不用聪兑合不以谈希言顺鸿蒙三者既关键缓体处空房委志归虚无无念以为常证难以推移心专不纵横寝寐神相抱觉悟候存亡颜容浸以润骨节益坚强排郄众阴邪然后立正阳修之不辍休庶炁云雨行淫淫如春泽液液象解冰从头流达足究竟复上升徃来洞无极怫怫被容中返者道之验弱者德之柄耘锄宿污秽细微得调畅浊者清之路昏久则昭明 耳 不听则坎水内澄目不视则离火内营口不言则兑金不鸣三者既闭则真人优游于其中须用无念无虑不可愁劳委志虚无心专不逸缓体处空房者无他意也 盖欲人守雌抱一缓弱其体独处空房之中寝寐则神相抱觉悟则审候存亡然后排郄阴邪纯阳积聚一身之中太和充溢象解冰之液液如春泽之融融庶炁云行如雨如雾上下徃来从头达足修之不辍污秽尽除筋骨调畅颜容光润骨节坚强血化白膏神形俱妙但七门既返殆若亡生百脉俱沉形炁消尽力弱不支昏浊如醉此乃道之验德之柄也 昏者明之基浊者清之源自兹以徃圆明洞照虚彻灵通莫不自昏浊始也 世人好小术不审道浅深弃正从邪径欲速阏不通犹盲不任杖聋者听商宫没水捕雉兔登山索鱼龙植麦欲获黍运规以求方竭力劳精神终年不见功欲知服食法事约而不繁 世人弃正从邪嗜好小术徒劳心力至老无成焉知大道之妙至简至易约而不繁者哉 太阳流珠常欲去人卒得金华转而相因化为白液凝而至坚金华先唱有顷之间解化为水马齿琅玕阳乃徃和情性自然迫促时阴拘蓄禁门慈母养育孝子报恩严父施令教勅子孙五行错王相据以生火性销金金伐木荣三五与一天地至精可以口诀难以书人命在卯日出于卯而万物仰之以生是则万物皆借太阳之精以立命矣 太阳流珠者命宝也 其此命宝寓神则营营而乱思乱思则逐物而迁化矣 寓精则持盈而难保难保则挠念欲泄矣 故曰常欲去人但世人之知是理者鲜矣 虽知之而能存者又鲜矣
chunks.translated_text:
Should one ask, "Why not leap beyond the radiance of the pearl?"—then let the inner body surge forth, ascending straight to the Purple Tenuity Palace. The yang-burning mirror draws fire, yet without the sun, no light is born; the moonlit vessel gathers dew, yet without stars and moon, how could water be obtained? The two qi, profound and distant, still respond to transformation—how much more so when near at hand, stored within the heart and breast? Yin and yang pair as sun and moon; water and fire serve as their signs.

The *yang-sui* is a mirror forged from five-colored stone, which, when turned toward the sun with mugwort, captures fire. The *Huainanzi* calls it the "fire vessel." There is also the "water vessel," a moonlit orb of crystal that, when turned toward the moon, gathers fire—this is called the *yin-sui*. Without the aid of sun and moon, neither vessel can generate water or draw fire. Within the human body, the ascent and descent of yin and yang move in harmony with the transformations of heaven and earth. How could the principle of water and fire’s communion lie beyond the mechanism of the sun and moon’s ebb and flow, by which we seek verification?

The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—must be firmly sealed, their apertures unopened. The Perfected One, concealed in the deep abyss, floats and drifts, abiding within the compass of the center. Whether turning or bending, seeing or hearing, opening or closing, all are governed by the self’s pivot. In movement and stillness, unceasing, the inner *qi* of *li* and *kan* nurtures defense and nourishment. The ears do not employ their acuity; the mouth does not engage in speech. Rare words follow the flow of the primordial flood. Once these three are secured, the body relaxes in an empty chamber, the will entrusted to emptiness. Absence of thought becomes the norm; the mind, undistracted, does not stray. In sleep, spirit and soul embrace; upon waking, one attends to the signs of presence and absence. The complexion gradually moistens; the bones and joints grow ever stronger. Expelling the host of yin’s perverse influences, one then establishes the true yang, cultivating it without cease. The *qi* of clouds and rain moves in gentle descent, like spring’s drizzle, like melting ice. From the head it flows to the feet, then ascends once more, circulating through the boundless. The returning glow within is the proof of the Dao; suppleness is the handle of virtue. Weeding and hoeing the long-accumulated filth, even the finest dust is smoothed away. The path of the turbid is made clear; long dimness is illuminated.

If the ears do not listen, the water of *kan* inwardly clarifies. If the eyes do not see, the fire of *li* inwardly nourishes. If the mouth does not speak, the metal of *dui* remains silent. Once these three are closed, the Perfected One roams freely within. One must employ absence of thought and worry, not indulge in toil. The will is entrusted to emptiness; the mind, undiverted, does not wander. To relax the body in an empty chamber—what other purpose is there? It is simply that one must embrace the feminine, hold to the One, and soften the body, dwelling alone in stillness. In sleep, spirit and soul embrace; upon waking, one attends to the signs of presence and absence. Then, expelling the perverse yin, pure yang accumulates within the body. Supreme harmony overflows, like melting ice, like spring’s gentle rain. The *qi* of clouds moves like mist, ascending and descending, flowing from head to feet. Cultivating this without cease, filth is wholly removed, sinews and bones harmonized, the complexion luminous, the bones and joints firm. The blood transforms into white marrow; spirit and form attain perfection. Yet once the seven gates are returned, one seems nearly lifeless: the hundred vessels sink, the form and *qi* dissolve, strength fails, and one cannot rise. Dazed and turbid, as if drunk—this is the proof of the Dao, the handle of virtue.

Dimness is the foundation of clarity; turbidity is the source of purity. From this point onward, round brilliance pervades, empty and penetrating, numinous and unobstructed—yet all begins in dimness and turbidity. Worldly people favor petty arts, failing to discern the depth of the Dao. They abandon the true and follow the perverse, seeking shortcuts that lead nowhere, like the blind refusing a staff, or the deaf attempting to hear the *shang* note. They fish for pheasants and hares in the water, hunt for dragons and fish on the mountain, plant wheat hoping for millet, or use a compass to seek a square. They exhaust their spirit and strength year after year, yet see no result.

Would you know the method of ingesting the elixir? It is simple, not complex. Worldly people abandon the true and follow the perverse, indulging in petty arts, wasting their minds and strength until old age, yet achieving nothing. How could they know the wonder of the Great Dao, which is utterly simple, utterly easy, concise and not cumbersome?

The flowing pearl of the Great Yang ever seeks to depart from man. Should one suddenly obtain the Golden Flower, it turns and binds with it, transforming into a white liquid, congealing into something most firm. The Golden Flower first intones, and in a moment, dissolves into the Water Horse’s teeth, the langgan jade. The yang then harmonizes, and the nature of the emotions naturally hastens. When the time is right, yin gathers and restrains, the gate of compassion nurtures, the filial child repays kindness, the stern father issues commands, and the descendants are taught. The five phases clash and contend, fire’s nature melts metal, metal fells wood, and flourishing arises. The Three and Five unite with the One; heaven and earth’s purest essence can be transmitted by oral instruction but cannot be written in words.

Man’s life resides in *mao*; the sun emerges from *mao*, and the myriad things depend on it for birth. Thus, all things rely on the essence of the Great Yang to establish their lives. The flowing pearl of the Great Yang is the treasure of life. When this life-treasure lodges in spirit, it flits about in confusion; confused thoughts chase after things and are transformed. When it lodges in essence, it is difficult to preserve fullness; instability leads to scattered thoughts and leaking desires. Thus it is said: "It ever seeks to depart from man." Yet few among worldly people know this principle; even fewer, though they know it, can preserve it.

After ten months, it emerges from the womb, its bones pliable enough to coil, its flesh smooth as lead. Its length is an inch, its width slightly narrower. The Dharma-body resides within. chunks.original_text: 然太阳之宝本木魂之精若得金华而制伏之则化为白液凝作黄芽如马齿琅玕之状拘蓄酉门而成变化其法以五行吞啖之理如父驱子如子投母似母养育似子报恩故先用火销金次用金伐木皆如严父之驱子然后化为八水者木之母也 故曰母育复凝成金水者金之子自子变母故曰报恩其要不出三五与一所谓三五一都三个字古今明者实然稀苟不遇至人授之口诀岂可轻易以文字窥测天机也 耶 象彼仲冬节草木皆催伤佐阳诘贾旅人君深自藏象时顺节令闭口不用谈天道甚浩广太无形容虚寂不可睹匡郭以消亡谬误失事绪言还自败伤别序斯四象以晓后生盲 仲冬之节万物归根当斯之时造化难测观夫天道则闭塞不通浩广而难知察彼太则虚寂沦无形之可睹果何据而测造化之机耶魏君别序四象以示后来具于下章 子当右转午乃东旋卯酉界隔主客二名龙呼于虎虎吸龙精两相饮食俱相贪荣遂相衔咽咀嚼相吞荧惑守西太白经天杀气所临何有不倾狸犬守防鸟雀畏鹯各得其功何敢有声 子从右转来东卯午从东旋来西酉皆越九转也如此则龙从火里出虎向水中生荧惑守西而制金太白经天而昼见矣自然龙呼于虎虎吸龙精钟离先生诗云莫谓此身云是道独修一物是孤阴须知一阴一阳之谓道男女媾精万物化生而后可语还丹矣苟二物不合三五不交水火未济刚柔离分则阴阳隔绝天地闭塞所谓偏阴偏阳谓之疾也 坎男为月离女为日日以施德月以舒光月受日化体不亏伤阳失其契阴侵其明晦朔薄蚀掩冒相倾阳消其形阴凌灾生男女相须含吐以滋雌雄错杂以相求 天地所以能长久者以日月徃来阴阳交防相资以发光辉一才失度则有薄蚀之患人之坎离犹天地之日月也能以盗天地之机乎 金化为水水性周章火化为土水不得行故男动外施女静内藏溢度过节为女所拘魄以钤魂不得淫奢不寒不暑进退合时各得其和俱吐证符 此言金水为夫妻水火为配耦之妙金生水水性湿苟无土以制之则未免过溢之患木生火火生土土生而后水不得行拘收藏蓄而与火为配耦是则金木相克得为夫妇者假火之力也水火相克而为配耦者假土之力也然后进退合时各得其和而随时变现俱吐证符矣 丹砂木精得金乃并金水合处木火为侣四者混沌列为龙虎龙阳数奇虎阴数偶肝青为父肺白为母肾黑为子脾黄为祖子五行始三物一家都归戊巳 金木甲庚相资为用者彼此怀真土也金四与水一合化土五木三与火二合化土五虽东木之龙西金之虎东三西四奇偶不齐及乎分作三家合成一舍则都归戊巳矣 刚柔迭兴更历分部龙西虎东建纬卯酉刑德并防相见欢喜刑主伏杀德主生起二月榆落魁临于卯八月麦生天罡据酉子南午北互为纲纪一九之数终而复始含元虚危播精于子 自子至已为干刚自午至亥为坤柔识此迭兴之理则自然龙西虎东子南午北建纬卯酉生起杀伏互为纲纪各得时矣二月本生起而西酉临之故榆死归根八月本杀伏而东卯临之故荠麦发生自西卯顺行九转然后见南方之子自东酉逆行九转然后见北方虚危此一九之数含元虚危播精于子者此也 关关睢鸠在河之洲窈窕淑女君子好逑雄不独处雌不孤居武蛇蟠虬相扶以明牝牡竟当相须假使二女共室颜色甚姝令苏秦通言张仪结媒发辨利舌奋舒美辞推心调谐合为夫妻敝发腐齿终不相知若药物非种名不同分刻参差失其纪纲虽黄帝临炉太乙执火八公捣炼淮南调合立宇崇坛玉为阶陛麟脯腊把籍长跪祷祝神祗请哀诸沐浴斋戒冀有所望亦犹和胶补釡以硵涂疮去泠加冰除用汤飞舞蛇愈见乖张

Yet the treasure of the Great Yang is fundamentally the essence of the wood-soul. If it obtains the golden radiance to subdue and master it, it transforms into a white liquid, congealing into the yellow sprout—like horse’s teeth or lustrous jade. Confined and nurtured within the Gate of *you*, it undergoes transformation. The method follows the principle of the Five Phases’ mutual consumption: as a father drives his son, as a son returns to his mother, as a mother nurtures, as a child repays kindness. Thus, one first employs fire to melt metal, then metal to fell wood—all like a stern father driving his son. Thereafter, it transforms into the Eight Waters, which are the mother of wood. Hence it is said: "The mother nurtures." Once more it congeals into metal-water, which is the child of metal. The child transforms into the mother, and thus it is said: "The child repays kindness." Its essentials do not exceed the Three, the Five, and the One. The Three, the Five, and the One—these three characters—are such that those who truly understand them in ancient and modern times are indeed rare. Unless one encounters a perfected person to transmit the oral instructions, how could one lightly presume to fathom the celestial mechanism through written words?

Alas! Consider the mid-winter season, when grasses and trees are all withered and harmed, aiding the Yang to interrogate the traveling merchants. The noble ruler deeply conceals himself, aligning with the season’s rhythms, closing his mouth and refraining from discoursing on the Dao of Heaven—so vast, so profound, formless and boundless, invisible and unfathomable. How could one rely on mere frameworks to dispel errors and avoid the entanglements of misguided words, which only bring self-defeat? Thus, I distinguish these Four Images to enlighten later generations of the blind.

At the mid-winter season, the myriad things return to their roots. At this time, the workings of creation are inscrutable. Observing the Dao of Heaven, one finds it sealed and impassable, vast and unknowable. Examining the Great Profundity, one finds it empty and still, swirling without form. On what basis, then, could one fathom the mechanism of creation? Master Wei distinguished the Four Images to instruct later generations, as set forth in the following chapter.

When *zi* turns right, *wu* rotates east; *mao* and *you* form the boundary between host and guest. The dragon calls to the tiger, the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence. Both feast upon each other, each coveting the other’s glory, until they interlock, swallow, chew, and devour one another. When Mars guards the west and Venus traverses the heavens, the killing energy descends—what could withstand its overthrow? The fox and dog guard against it, birds and sparrows fear the goshawk. Each fulfills its function—how dare they make a sound?

*Zi* turns right to come east, *wu* rotates east to come west to *you*—each traverses nine revolutions. Thus, the dragon emerges from within fire, the tiger is born within water. Mars guards the west to restrain metal, Venus traverses the heavens and appears by day. Naturally, the dragon calls to the tiger, the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence. Master Zhongli’s poem says: "Do not say this body is the Dao, cultivated alone; a single thing is but solitary Yin. Know that the Dao is the union of one Yin and one Yang. Only after male and female unite, essence intermingles, and the myriad things are transformed, can one speak of the Returned Elixir. If the two things do not unite, the Three and Five do not intersect, water and fire remain unbridged, hardness and softness separate—then Yin and Yang are cut off, heaven and earth sealed. This is what is called ‘partial Yin, partial Yang’—a malady indeed."

Kan (the trigram) is the male, the moon; Li is the female, the sun. The sun bestows its virtue, the moon unfurls its light. The moon receives the sun’s transformation, its body unharmed. If the Yang loses its contract, the Yin encroaches upon its brightness; at conjunction and opposition, eclipses occur, one overshadowing the other. The Yang’s form is consumed, the Yin’s calamity arises. Male and female require each other, inhaling and exhaling to nourish; female and male intermingle, seeking one another.

That by which heaven and earth endure is the sun and moon’s reciprocal movement, Yin and Yang’s mutual containment and support to emit radiance. If even one deviates from its measure, there arises the peril of eclipses. The Kan and Li of man are like the sun and moon of heaven and earth—how could one not steal the mechanism of heaven and earth?

Metal transforms into water, and water’s nature is pervasive. Fire transforms into earth, and water cannot flow. Thus, the male moves and externally bestows, the female is still and internally conceals. If the overflow exceeds its measure, it is restrained by the female; the po controls the hun, preventing excess. Neither cold nor heat, advancing and retreating in timely fashion, each attains harmony and together they emit confirming signs.

This speaks of the marvel of metal-water as husband and wife, water-fire as mates. Metal generates water, and water’s nature is moist. Without earth to restrain it, there would inevitably be the peril of overflow. Wood generates fire, fire generates earth, and only when earth is generated can water be restrained, gathered, stored, and mated with fire. Thus, metal and wood, though mutually destructive, become husband and wife by virtue of fire’s power. Water and fire, though mutually destructive, become mates by virtue of earth’s power. Thereafter, advancing and retreating in timely fashion, each attains harmony and manifests transformations in accord with the season, together emitting confirming signs.

Cinnabar is the essence of wood. When it obtains metal, they unite; where metal and water converge, wood and fire become companions. The four intermingle in chaos, arrayed as dragon and tiger. The dragon is Yang, its number odd; the tiger is Yin, its number even. The liver, green, is the father; the lungs, white, are the mother; the kidneys, black, are the child; the spleen, yellow, is the ancestor. The child and the Five Phases begin with three things—a single family all returning to *wu* and *si*.

Metal and wood—A and Geng—mutually support each other’s use, for both embrace true earth. Metal (four) and water (one) combine to transform into earth (five). Wood (three) and fire (two) combine to transform into earth (five). Though the dragon of eastern wood and the tiger of western metal—east three and west four—are odd and even, unequal, when divided into three families and united into one dwelling, they all return to *wu-si*.

Hardness and softness alternate in ascent, traversing the divisions. The dragon is west, the tiger east; *mao* and *you* establish the warp, punishment and virtue are both contained, and they meet in joy. Punishment governs subduing and killing, virtue governs generation and ascent. In the second month, the elm withers, the Dipper points to *mao*; in the eighth month, wheat sprouts, the Celestial Stem resides in *you*. *Zi* is south, *wu* is north, mutually serving as the guiding principles. The number one-nine ends and begins anew, containing the Primordial within the Void and Danger, sowing essence in *zi*.

From *zi* to *si* is Qian, the hard; from *wu* to *hai* is Kun, the soft. Understanding this principle of alternating ascent, one naturally finds the dragon in the west, the tiger in the east; *zi* in the south, *wu* in the north; *mao* and *you* establishing the warp; generation and killing, ascent and subduing, mutually serving as guiding principles, each attaining its time. In the second month, generation begins, and *you* descends upon it—thus the elm dies and returns to its root. In the eighth month, killing and subduing prevail, and *mao* descends upon it—thus shepherd’s purse and wheat sprout. From *you* to *mao*, proceeding in nine revolutions, one then sees *zi* in the south. From *mao* to *you*, reversing in nine revolutions, one then sees the Void and Danger in the north. This is what is meant by "the number one-nine contains the Primordial within the Void and Danger, sowing essence in *zi*."

The *guan-guan* ospreys on the river isle, the graceful and virtuous maiden—how the noble man longs for her! The male does not dwell alone, the female does not live in solitude. The dark warrior and the coiling dragon, the entwined serpents—all illustrate how male and female must rely on each other. Suppose two women share a chamber, their complexions fair, and one sends Su Qin to convey words, Zhang Yi to arrange the match, untying their braids, loosening their tongues, flaunting their eloquence, and deploying honeyed speech to persuade and harmonize, intending to unite as husband and wife. Yet even if their hair rots and their teeth decay, they will never know each other. If the medicinal substances are not of the same kind, their *qi* and essences differ, their measures and timings are misaligned, and their guiding principles lost—then even if the Yellow Emperor tends the furnace, Taiyi wields the fire, the Eight Lords pound and refine, Huainan harmonizes the mixture, a towering altar is raised, jade steps and terraces built, unicorn jerky and dried meat offered, registers held, long kneeling in prayer, spirits and deities entreated, the hundred demons beseeched, ablutions and fasting observed, all in hope of some result—it would be like using glue to mend a cauldron, salt to treat a wound, adding ice to dispel cold, or boiling water to make serpents dance. The more one does, the more perverse it becomes.

When it lodges in essence, it is difficult to preserve fullness; instability leads to scattered thoughts and leaking desires. Thus it is said: "It ever seeks to depart from man." Yet few among worldly people know this principle; even fewer, though they know it, can preserve it.
